articles.headline: Fed Cuts U.S. Growth Forecast for 2013 and 2014
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve also said it would not expand its stimulus campaign despite the slow pace of job growth.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve also said it would not expand its stimulus campaign despite the slow pace of job growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, on Wednesday dismissed proposals to escalate the Fed’s economic stimulus campaign as “reckless,” arguing that the costs would be high and the benefits uncertain.

articles.headline: Double-Dip Recession in Britain
articles.snippet: The figures provoked an outcry in Britain, and came the same day that Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, shifted his rhetoric on the debt crisis to add emphasis on growth.
articles.abstract: The figures provoked an outcry in Britain, and came the same day that Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, shifted his rhetoric on the debt crisis to add emphasis on growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain has fallen into its first double-dip recession since the 1970s, according to official figures released Wednesday, a development that raised more questions about whether government belt-tightening in Europe has gone too far.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Ousted Chinese Leader Is Said to Have Spied on Other Top Officials
articles.snippet: Bo Xilai was toppled amid accusations that his wife arranged the killing of a British businessman, but wiretapping may have been another compelling reason party officials turned on him.
articles.abstract: Bo Xilai was toppled amid accusations that his wife arranged the killing of a British businessman, but wiretapping may have been another compelling reason party officials turned on him.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When Hu Jintao, China’s top leader, picked up the telephone last August to talk to a senior anticorruption official visiting Chongqing, special devices detected that he was being wiretapped — by local officials in that southwestern metropolis.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Ansfield and Ian Johnson

articles.headline: With Wal-Mart Claims, Greater Attention on a Law
articles.snippet: The bribery allegations surrounding Wal-Mart cast into relief the transformation of the once-obscure Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, a law enacted in 1977 that was rarely enforced.
articles.abstract: The bribery allegations surrounding Wal-Mart cast into relief the transformation of the once-obscure Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, a law enacted in 1977 that was rarely enforced.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A decade ago, the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which bars American companies from bribing officials overseas, was rarely enforced or discussed. Today, it strikes fear throughout the executive offices of companies with overseas operations, generating huge fees for law firms and large fines for the federal government.

articles.headline: Chasing Fees, Banks Court Low-Income Customers
articles.snippet: More large banks are aggressively pursuing low-income customers with products that can carry high fees and are largely untouched by consumer protections.
articles.abstract: More large banks are aggressively pursuing low-income customers with products that can carry high fees and are largely untouched by consumer protections.
articles.lead_paragraph: When David Wegner went looking for a checking account in January, he was peppered with offers for low-end financial products, including a prepaid debit card with numerous fees, a short-term emergency loan with steep charges, money wire services and check-cashing options.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: At Disney, It’s Tough to Find a Chief
articles.snippet: A difficult question has emerged as Walt Disney Studios searches for a new chairman, with no obvious candidates: Does the job require a brand manager or a strong movie hand?
articles.abstract: A difficult question has emerged as Walt Disney Studios searches for a new chairman, with no obvious candidates: Does the job require a brand manager or a strong movie hand?
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — At a convention of movie theater owners here on Tuesday, Walt Disney Studios displayed plenty of fanfare, trotting out Johnny Depp to promote his 2013 remake of “The Lone Ranger” and hiring 11 bagpipe players to herald “Brave,” a film about a Scottish princess.

articles.headline: 2 House Democrats Defeated After Opposing Health Law
articles.snippet: The defeat of two conservative Pennsylvania representatives, Jason Altmire and Tim Holden, by more liberal opponents foreshadows an even more polarized Congress next year.
articles.abstract: The defeat of two conservative Pennsylvania representatives, Jason Altmire and Tim Holden, by more liberal opponents foreshadows an even more polarized Congress next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The defeat of two conservative House Democrats by more liberal opponents in Tuesday’s Pennsylvania primary illustrates the strong hold the new health care law still has over committed Democratic voters and foreshadows an even more polarized Congress next year in the aftermath of the latest round of redistricting.

articles.headline: Black Man’s Killing in Georgia Eludes Spotlight
articles.snippet: Despite the similarities with the Trayvon Martin case, the death of Justin Patterson did not receive the same attention.
articles.abstract: Despite the similarities with the Trayvon Martin case, the death of Justin Patterson did not receive the same attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: LYONS, Ga. — Norman Neesmith was sleeping in his home on a rural farm road here in onion country when a noise woke him up.

articles.headline: Chrysler Reports Strong First-Quarter Results
articles.snippet: The carmaker’s profit of $473 million was attributed to an overhaul of a large portion of its product lineup and the use of creative, high-profile advertising to attract new customers.
articles.abstract: The carmaker’s profit of $473 million was attributed to an overhaul of a large portion of its product lineup and the use of creative, high-profile advertising to attract new customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Chrysler, broken down, bankrupt and begging for a bailout just three years ago, is now a shiny new sports car zipping past the competition.

articles.headline: Trouble With the Top Man
articles.snippet: Chesapeake Energy, whose stock has fallen 45 percent in a year, said it would not extend a controversial compensation plan for Aubrey McClendon that provided him with a right to personally invest in the company’s new wells.
articles.abstract: Chesapeake Energy, whose stock has fallen 45 percent in a year, said it would not extend a controversial compensation plan for Aubrey McClendon that provided him with a right to personally invest in the company’s new wells.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  — Aubrey K. McClendon, Chesapeake Energy’s audacious chairman and chief executive, has ridden the busts and booms in natural gas like a rodeo cowboy. He became a billionaire as the company he co-founded aggressively outbid competitors for land leases and drilled highly productive wells in virtually every major shale gas field in the country. And he acquired trophy assets like an N.B.A. team and a $12 million antique map collection.

articles.headline: An Aging Japanese Town Bets on a Young Mayor for Its Revival
articles.snippet: Yubari is hoping that 31-year-old Naomichi Suzuki can turn around its deep debt and troubling demographics.
articles.abstract: Yubari is hoping that 31-year-old Naomichi Suzuki can turn around its deep debt and troubling demographics.
articles.lead_paragraph: YUBARI, Japan — Most young people have already fled this city of empty streets and shuttered schools, whose bankrupt local government collapsed under the twin burdens of debt and demographics that are slowly afflicting the rest of Japan.
